title: Before 1 January 2018, will Iran's monthly oil production exceed 4 million barrels per day?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in the next week.
Maintaining forecast based on @dsarin's OPEC stats update.

Crude Oil Production in Iran increased to 3878 BBL/D/1K in November from 3810 BBL/D/1K in October of 2017. Crude Oil Production in Iran averaged 3551.31 BBL/D/1K from 1973 until 2017, reaching an all time high of 6677 BBL/D/1K in November of 1976 and a record low of 510 BBL/D/1K in October of 1980.

Most recent Reuters survey puts Iran's oil production for November at 3.82mb/d (+10tb/d from October). If the data from Reuters is similar to OPEC’s MOMR released on December 13, that gives Iran a month to add more than 180,000 b/d…
https://uk.reuters.com/article/opec-oil/table-opec-oil-output-falls-by-300000-bpd-in-november-reuters-survey-idUKL8N1O433T

U.S. Congress have under a month to decide whether to reimpose sanctions on Iran in relation to the JCPOA. If sanctions were reimposed, its unlikely to effect Iran’s oil production in the short-term. 
Reuters reported: “NIOC has offered spot cargoes, ranging from light to heavy crudes, to its term buyers in Asia, after setting December prices at the lowest in years against comparable Saudi grades, three sources with knowledge of the matter said.”
“Discounts were made to retain existing buyers of Iranian oil, which already have government-backed agreements in place from when the original western sanctions hit Iran’s oil exports in 2012-2014.” (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-asia-iran-oil/iran-pushes-to-retain-asia-oil-buyers-as-possible-u-s-sanctions-loom-idUSKBN1DR0JS)
unlikely with the current rise of oil production in USA and the Asian demand for it.
3.823 million for October. Down from September.
Dropping to zero as Iran has clearly stabilized at just over 3.8 million barrels per day.

Reuters OPEC output survey for October shows Iran producing 3.81mb/d. (https://www.cnbc.com/2017/10/31/reuters-america-table-opec-oil-output-falls-by-80000-bpd-in-october--reuters-survey.html) showing no change from September output. Don't expect much difference in OPEC's survey.

Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Still hovering at about 3.8 million b/d (since Q1 2017). 3.827 million for September, slightly more than August.

Revising downwards. Production has been flat around 3.82-83 million barrels/day for several months. It seems that the desire to increase production beyond this level doesn't exist, rather than any technical barriers. The recovery in oil prices after OPEC introduced production cuts probably plays a part here. Hence it seems very unlikely that Iran will cross 4 million bpd - not till OPEC has a production cap.

Oil production in Iran will reach four million bpd by the beginning of the next Iranian calendar year (March 21), National Iranian Oil Company Managing Director Ali Kardor said on February 18.
http://www.tehrantimes.com/news/411541/Iranian-oil-output-to-exceed-3-9m-bpd-in-Feb-Zanganeh
It is 3.83 billion barrels currently. Close but with only 3 months left to go, probably not by the deadline.

Iran’s oil minister, Bijan Zanganeh “confirmed that production was more than 3.8mb/d. ‘We hope to increase oil production capacity in the coming months. We can do that with development of the West Karun oil fields and also South Pars gas condensates." (https://www.platts.com/latest-news/oil/london/analysis-iranian-oil-flows-gain-further-ground-26801813) 
Contrary to this, Zanganeh spoke on the topic of OPEC: “OPECs actions are working and compliance is acceptable overall, although there needs to be some change. Changes are really related to Libya and Nigeria and the one hundred percent compliance of everyone.” When asked whether the country would adjust its output, Zanganeh responded: “Iran will consider everything within the framework of our national interest and cooperation with OPEC.” (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-24/iran-says-opec-action-on-output-cuts-must-address-libya-nigeria))
Reducing from 5% for passage of time. Iran's output has remained fairly steady this year, fluctuating around 3.8 mbpd.
Production has been stable around 3.8 MM b/d since early 2017.
Like China, Iran can barely run a cold bath.

Maintaining forecast: A recent Reuters survey puts Iran’s August oil output at 3.79mb/d - I would, therefore, expect no dramatic increases in the next OPEC MOMR. https://uk.reuters.com/article/opec-oil/table-opec-oil-output-falls-by-170000-bpd-in-august-reuters-survey-idUKL8N1LH3OE
Probably not. Production is holding steady for first and second quarters.

“According to Ali Kador, chief executive of NIOC, Iran is pumping 3.95mb/d with exports at 2.2mb/d, ISNA reported on Wednesday. That is 50,000 barrels higher than what Iran reported to OPEC in July” (https://financialtribune.com/articles/energy/71018/irans-kharg-daily-oil-exports-at-21m-barrels). And it is 126,000 barrels higher than OPECs secondary sources data. 
“Production is currently at 80,000 b/d from South Azadegan. Plans are in place to double the volume by the end of the fiscal year in March 2018.” (https://financialtribune.com/articles/energy/71020/irans-first-ipc-based-oil-tender-to-be-finalized-in-8-months) 
Adding 80,000 barrels to Iran’s current production level (based on secondary sources) will not take it to 4mb/d by the end of 2017 unless production is increased at other locations. 
Will continue to look for other locations where Iran announces plans to increase output.
Forget OPEC China Controls Oil Prices

Iran is non-compliant to the OPEC deal again, based on data for July. With the governments target of 4mb/d by March 2018, Iran doesn’t show any willingness to maintain output at 3,790tb/d. That being said, if the OPEC deal fails in the last few months of the year - I don’t see there being much impact on Iran’s output (maybe their exports) as it would appear they do not have the capacity, at present.

The Iraq-Iran plan to build a pipeline that would export crude oil from the northern Iraqi field of Kirkuk via Iran has currently reached an impasse. 
“Kirkuk refuses to cooperate with any plans to ship its oil to neighbouring Iran because the central government didn’t consult with it on the matter,” Kirkuk Provincial officials said.
“The central government in Baghdad and the semiautonomous Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) both pump crude from different wells at Kirkuk’s oil fields.”
“KRG has announced it will hold a referendum on independence from Iraq on September 25, including in Kirkuk. This has angered authorities in Iran and Turkey…and drawn criticism from the U.S. saying the step would be destabilising” (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-03/iraq-s-kirkuk-province-spurns-plan-to-ship-its-oil-to-iran)

Dropping thanks to another three months of data. Iran has held steady in it's production so I no longer think they will exceed 4 million barrels per day.

Iran’s crude oil production rose above 3.8 MMbpd in June, and in terms of capacity it can produce 4 MMbpd any time it wants to.  On June 24, Iran’s oil minister stated that Iran would ramp up production to 4 MMbpd after the expiry of the OPEC production cut deal in March 2018.  I forecast that Iran will increase production to 4MMbpd sooner, sometime in Q4 of 2017, as sustained oil prices below $50 pinch Gulf budgets too much and lead to a breakdown in the OPEC production cut agreement by November, leading to OPEC members opening their taps to compete for market share and try once again to put small and medium-sized US tight oil producers (frackers) out of business.
Declining oil prices and challenges in gulf combined with US policies significantly reduce expectation

Major investment banks hastened to revise further down their oil price projections, seeing a flow of supply hitting the market as soon as production cuts expire in March 2018. Add the second U.S. shale boom to this, and it looks like the glut will return with a vengeance in 2018.

The projections are that Iran will produce less than 4 million barrels per day per month for the remainder of 2017. They are increasing their capacity, but it will probably not be until 2018 when they will produce at this level.

Iran’s oil minister said at the sidelines of a meeting with the European Commissioner for Climate Action and Energy: “During the past few days, we received positive signals from OPEC and non-members, in particular Russia, about extending the agreement for the second half of 2017. We will back the agreement” (https://financialtribune.com/articles/energy/63415/iran-oil-minister-backs-extension-of-crude-supply-cuts). I’m always skeptical about what Iran’s oil minister says as there is usually a lot of backtracking that occurs after a comment is made. However, I would think its likely that Iran will follow suit if other OPEC members agree for an extension. 
Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei recently said “Iranians should not thank Hassan Rouhani's policy of detente with the West for any reduction in the threat of war”.
Ebrahim Raisi, one of Rouhani’s main challengers said: "We should not warn our people of wars and crises. We have full security in the country. This approach, that we should wait for foreign investment and for foreigners to resolve our issues, is wrong. This is wrong, to wait years and years for foreign investors to come ... We should resolve issues by relying on domestic capabilities” (https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2017-04-30/irans-leader-dismisses-rouhanis-detente-policy-ahead-of-vote) 
The fact that Raisi’s comments seem to echo those of Khamenei suggest that the supreme leader is pushing Iranians to vote for hardliners. If Raisi genuinely means what he says and is voted as the next president, then its possible that Iran won’t be getting the investment they need to upgrade their oil fields, which in turn will impact the level of output.
Oil slips on OPEC cut extension doubts, Russia output worries

Iran is also putting 3 million barrels back into storage in May.” 
“In April the country is expected to export 1.8mb/d of crude and 370,000 b/d of condensate, down from 2.9mb/d reached in February.” 
(http://www.reuters.com/article/iran-oil-exports-idUSL3N1HT1QS)

In terms of realism, a nation will not disapprove of a wealthy economy or any factor that may contribute to develop such. Thus, we may assume for this prediction that Iran is continuously seeking to increase its total revenue, to secure itself as a socially, politically and militarily powerful international actor. The first graph indicates that Iran’s main source of revenue is oil with only 11 percent of its GDP being obtained otherwise (fig. 1). Additionally, to further understand the importance of oil to the economy of Iran, recent studies have shown that since the lifting of the P5 imposed sanctions on Iran in 2016 - initially imposed due to its threatening nuclear program (Labott, 2015) – its oil exports have tripled (Egan, 2017). With a current crude oil production of approximately 3.8 million barrels per day (bpd) (fig. 2), researchers seek to find out whether Iran’s monthly oil production will exceed the 4 million bpd mark by the beginning of 2018. The following will provide an insight into whether these numbers are actually achievable. 
 	According to the senior consultant of research for JBC Energy, these numbers are only achievable if Iran’s technological capacities to extract crude oil are modernized (Egan, 2017). Relying heavily on foreign interest, Iran has therefore composed the Iran Petroleum Contract. Its terms state that there will be an increase in profits obtainable by foreign investors and the guarantee of revenue due to a newly developed risk service (Willn, 2015). Herewith, Iran is aiming to cover its issue of outdated extracting technology: a profound hurdle to achieving reach the newly set mark. However, as argued by O’Donnell, not all terms have been ‘spelled out’ fully yet, due to Iran’s fear of foreign investments causing troubles in regards to social security through instances such as job-loss for local workers etc. (Egan, 2017).
 	It is important to note however that Iran has strong geostrategic interests in the Middle East, especially in regards to the sectarian war in Syria (Gause, 2017). Simply put, more investments imply greater oil revenues and greater oil revenues lead to more money: a needed means for the feasibility of Iran’s geostrategic interests. As Iran is ranked by the CIA as the 16th most prominent international oil exporter its exports are far below those of its competitors Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates ("The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency", 2017). Thus, in order to boost its power in and over unstable parts of the region, I would like to stress that it will be unlikely for Iran to oppose foreign interest. In fact, only recently Iran has “vowed to increase” oil exports to buyers in the European Union (Levit, 2017)., providing an insight into its willingness to rise through the ranks and to turn a blind eye to possible social security issues.
 	In sum, the outdated infrastructure and technology to extract crude oil are leading Iran to attract foreign investors. With an influx of investors, the country is promised an increase in oil production, and foremost an increase in profit. Even though the presence of foreign companies may imply precarious working conditions for the Iranian oil labourers, Iran’s geostrategic interests display that Iran may be willing to overlook this social issue. Additionally, as the current number of barrels produced per month has already reached 3.8 million – and noting that we are only in the first third of 2017 – we may assume Iran to be exceeding the 4 million mark before the end of the year.
Trend increase of 50k bpd per month.

Raising slightly due to latest projection of current growth rate showing 4m being reached in August-September. Still think it will be tough to go over the mark due to infrastructure limits and OPEC crackdown.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

: Oil wells at Iran’s South Pars gasfield started production for the first time on Sunday, Iranian oil ministry news agency SHANA reported. South Pars is a part of the world’s largest gasfield which Iran shares with Qatar. South Pars also has more than 14 billion barrels of oil reserves, it said.
Iraqi oil minister: market is decisive factor in possible cut extension

Iran has started production from seven wells at the South Pars field at 35,000 b/d. (http://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/Irans-14-Billion-Barrel-Oil-Field-Comes-Online.html) This figure is expected to increase to 100,000 b/d in the second phase (I haven’t found a date for when this is set to begin). 
According to the Iranian Minister of Petroleum, Bijan Zangeneh, “Iran has plans to raise production of oil and gas from the joint field to levels higher than that of Qatar” (http://www.nioc-intl.ir/WebSiteEn/Pages/News1.aspx) 
In relation to what Iran will do later on in the year: there was an article published on Platts on the 22nd March 2017, in reference to Saudi Arabia, Iran and production cuts; “Geopolitical rivals Saudi Arabia and Iran may be headed for another OPEC showdown as the producer group enters negotiations over extending oil production cuts in force since January” 
“Any move to rein in Iran’s production is likely to be met with significant resistance, experts say.” 
Given the improvement in Iran’s oil production since January 2016, it can only be expected that any member, especially Saudi Arabia, telling Iran to rein in their production will not be taken lightly. 
(http://www.platts.com/latest-news/oil/london/saudi-arabia-may-insist-on-iran-oil-output-cuts-26691454) 
This might lead to an interesting period between now and June, when the original agreement ends. Last April, when OPEC attempted to construct a production cut deal, Saudi Arabia and Iran could not level with each other. “Iran wanted an exemption while it recovered from sanctions which prompted Saudi Arabia to withdraw from negotiations”. (http://www.platts.com/latest-news/oil/london/saudi-arabia-may-insist-on-iran-oil-output-cuts-26691454). In September, the OPEC members came back together in Algiers, some more willing to cut production, and negotiations were ongoing for 3 months, until November 30th when the agreement was signed. Coming back to what is happening now, if we are seeing Iran and Saudi Arabia heading for the same show down, there might be a period where there is no deal in place, allowing Iran (and other members) to produce at volumes they choose and are capable of doing.

Secondly, Iran was not subject to the production cut agreed to by OPEC in late 2016 - because its exports had been hit by US driven sanctions. So the 'cut' doesn't apply to Iran.

At the same time, other sources are predicting that oil production will peak at 3.7m (http://crudeoilpeak.info/iran-peak), but Iran is already producing more than the forecasts in this example.

Apologies if any of this has been said previously: It looks highly likely that Iran's monthly oil production will exceed 4 mb/d before January 2018. Iran is actively looking to diversify and expand their customer base, especially in Europe, and have already sold oil cargoes to companies such as BP, Total (Iran's exports to France increased 57% m-o-m in September'16, all of which goes to Total), Repsol (Spain), Petrogal (Portugal), Iplom (Italy) etc. Iranian crude oil is appealing to European buyers due to competitive pricing compared to crudes from Russia and the Persian Gulf (platts.com).
India and China are still the main buyers for Iranian crude oil - with India importing 602,456 b/d in September (up from 458,880 b/d in August) and their GDP forecasted to grow 7.2% in 2017 (OPEC MOMR October'16) , oil imports are likely to increase too. 
Also need to consider the influence of the upcoming OPEC meeting (as Iran is a member state). It was mentioned early on when talks about freezing production by OPEC were made public that Iran would be exempt from the deal, along with Nigeria and Libya. However, it now seems that the Saudi Arabians want to cut Iran's production (as mentioned by previous forecasters), making it increasingly harder for OPEC to agree a deal on November 30th. There are also problems from Iraq who do not want to cap production at the level OPEC is offering on the basis that they need the money to fight ISIS - increasing fears that a deal will not be made. 
It is necessary for Iran to get investment in order to exceed 4 mb/d due to major maintenance work and necessary technology upgrades - with the lifting of sanctions, Iran is looking for foreign investors for 50 new upstream projects (a list of qualified companies will be published December 7th 2016).
The deal signed with Total Oil from France moves this up a bit.
